back: a specificity value is expressed in four parts 0,0,0,0  * for every ID attr in the given selector  add 0,1,0,0 * for every class attr or pseudo-class in the selector  add 0,0,1,0 * for every element or pseudo-element in the selector  add 0,0,0,1 * combinators or universal selector do not contribute anything special

h1 {color: red;| /* specificity = 0,0,0,1 */ p em {color: purple;} /* specificity = 0,0,0,2 */ .grape{color: purple;} /* specificity = 0,0,1,0 */ *.bright {color: yellow;} /* specificity = 0,0,1,0 (/ p.bright em.dark {color: blue;} /* specificity = 0,0,2,2 */ #first-para {color: blue;} /* specificity = 0,1,0,0 */ * {color: gray;} /* specificity = 0,0,0,0 */
sometimes a declaration is so important that it outweights all other considerations  p.dark{color: black !important; background: while !important;}
mechanism by which styles are applied not only to the specified element but also to its descendents
what happens when two rules of equal specificity apply to the same element?  * sort by weight and origin * sorting by specificity * sorting by order
weight - if two rules apply to an element and one is marked !important the important rule wins out:  p{color: blue !important;} &ltp style='color: black;'&gt..&lt/p&gt css style wins
if an element is matched by normal-weight styles in both the author's style sheet and the reader's then the author's styles are used
if conflicting declarations apply to an element and they all have the same weight they should be sorted by specificity.
finally if two rules have exactly the same weight, origin, and specificity then the one that occurs later in the style sheet wins out
